sentences.english: On current form, this looks a tall order.
sentences.chinese: 照目前形势来看，这似乎有些赶鸭子上架。

sentences.english: You had to feel a bit sorry for the ever-willing Carrick and Fletcher at the back.
sentences.chinese: 你一定会同情被赶鸭子上架的卡里克和弗莱彻。

definition: if you ride a tiger, it's hard to get off (idiom); fig. impossible to stop halfway
to brace oneself to do sth/to put a bold face on it/to summon up courage/to force oneself to
driven to join the Liangshan Mountain rebels/to drive to revolt/to force sb to desperate action
to force someone to do something
to ask for trouble (idiom)/to make a rod for one's own back
Mao Sui recommends himself (idiom); to offer one's services (in the style of Mao Sui offering his services to king of Chu 楚 of the Warring states)
to tackle a difficult job (idiom)/to do sth reluctantly
to move a stone and stub one's toe/to shoot oneself in the foot (idiom)
